body: I did't find this text in druid code, I guess it is from jackson? Can you provide the error trace? @floondi

As @gianm and @pjain1 mentioned, there are a number of reasons why a task would be asked to stop before/during publishing in normal operation, the most common being in the case where you have replica tasks. If there are replica tasks, once one of them finishes publishing their segments, the remaining replicas are asked to stop, but these tasks haven't failed per se even though nothing was published, and marking them as failed tasks would not lead to a good experience.

Forcibly killing the task after a timeout so they return a failure status seems like a good solution to me. In the future, having more detailed return/error codes from tasks would be even better so that you could quickly determine why the task stopped running without having to dig through logs from the task or overlord.
@gianm you're right. I changed the title. Also, I'll fix the problem of publishing segments at the very end of the index task in a follow-up pr.
i updated the docs #4213 and release notes for 0.10.0 .

The test failure is probably in some way related to my change. Previously, no two ```SketchEstimatePostAggregator```s and ```SketchMergeAggregatorFactory```s containing a non-null ```errorBoundsStdDev``` will have been considered equal. Therefore, the ```Map``` used in the ```DruidCoordinatorTest``` may previously have stored two distinct objects that are now considered equal.

I don't know the code base and test well enough to fix this test, but it looks to me as if it's worth for someone else to take a look. The other alerts on lgtm.com are also really worth having a look at.

@sjvs, thanks for the contribution! The lgtm tool looks pretty cool. Is that something you made?

Also - could you fill out the CLA at http://druid.io/community/cla.html so we can accept your contribution?

The test failure is probably unrelated. That test is flaky sometimes (see #4202).

Style wise, could you please make a couple changes? Braces and line length don't match typical Druid code style -- there should be spaces between parens and braces, and lines shouldn't exceed 120 chars. We have formatting configs for IntelliJ and Eclipse in `druid_intellij_formatting.xml` and `eclipse_formatting.xml`.

Finally, a side note: most of our equals/hashCode methods are automatically generated using IntelliJ's equals/hashCode generator. I'm not sure why the one in those two files is wrong, since the latest version does generate them properly when I run the generator locally. Maybe the current code was written by hand or maybe an older version of IntelliJ had a bug in the generation.

If you're using IntelliJ locally, you might as well use it to both apply the code style and generate the equals method.

Thanks @gianm! Yes, I'm part of the team responsible for lgtm.com. Things are exciting here: we're just about to come out of beta, so we've started reaching out to OSS projects by contributing some PRs. Would love to hear your thoughts on lgtm.com - I'll contact you off-line if that's all right.

I've just signed the CLA, will make the requested changes now. Will give a shout when that's done.

Best of luck with the upcoming launch!

I went through some of the other alerts, and some of them are false positives. Are there any code comments or signals you understand for ignoring that kind of thing?

Examples:

https://lgtm.com/projects/g/druid-io/druid/snapshot/013566ade941151eb37d55a9c7efa4a9c28a3493/files/java-util/src/main/java/io/druid/java/util/common/io/smoosh/FileSmoosher.java#V436; the resource escapes the constructor but it's closed in a `close` method.

https://lgtm.com/projects/g/druid-io/druid/snapshot/013566ade941151eb37d55a9c7efa4a9c28a3493/files/bytebuffer-collections/src/main/java/io/druid/collections/bitmap/WrappedRoaringBitmap.java#V204; the stream isn't closed, but it doesn't need to be, since closing doesn't do anything.

https://lgtm.com/projects/g/druid-io/druid/snapshot/013566ade941151eb37d55a9c7efa4a9c28a3493/files/extendedset/src/main/java/io/druid/extendedset/intset/ConciseSet.java#V715; there's a comment noting that the bitwise OR is done on purpose.

@gianm: I've just fixed the coding style issues. Let me know if it's OK like this.

Re. the other lgtm.com alerts you mentioned: great feedback, thanks! I'll contact you off-line for further discussion.
Sure, go for it.

@nlokare you mean the "inline" maps? I would probably avoid them for anything larger than 100KB or so, but it should work higher than that (as you say you have 10MB maps). Certainly, storing them in files is more scalable than specifying them inline.

Yes http://druid.io/docs/latest/development/extensions-core/lookups-cached-global.html is the right place to look. I'm not sure if GCS lookups are supported though. I know S3 and HDFS are. You might be able to get GCS to work if you also include `google-extensions` which is a new community extension for Druid 0.10.

@gianm passing now

I think we need to call it out in the release notes and make both Duration and Period granularity behave in a consistent way. @himanshug: @gianm: @cheddar: Any thoughts on what should be the expected behavior ?
I think this isn't a real bug, because running in non-UTC timezones was never supported. And in UTC, the behavior didn't change.

See also configuration.md in the Druid docs which says,

> `-Duser.timezone=UTC` This sets the default timezone of the JVM to UTC. We always set this and do not test with other default timezones, so local timezones might work, but they also might uncover weird and interesting bugs. To issue queries in a non-UTC timezone, see [query granularities](../querying/granularities.html#period-granularities)

And really, I think the new behavior is helping get Druid in a state where we _could_ officially support running in different user timezones. It implemented part of the ask from #2619 and #1204.

the doc mentions following about DurationGranularities - 
"They also support specifying an optional origin, which defines where to start counting time buckets from (defaults to 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z)." 
If I create a DurationGranularity and serialize the query on client side, it will pick the origin based on the timezone of client VM instead of defaulting to 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z. 
So I think, we need to fix the DurationGranularity to be able to distinguish between when a user has actually set origin or not and default to UTC when user has not set any origin. This will make both Period and Duration granularities behave in same way. does that seem a reasonable fix ?
Yeah, changing DurationGranularity to set default origins in UTC does seem reasonable.

I'm pretty sure Kafka requires these libs to function they hard reference some of the log4j classes
Or maybe I'm thinking of the raw log4j and not the slf4j bridge

They are already in the classpath because they are supplied by Druid. By adding this exclusion, one of the duplicate bindings disappears from the SLF4J warning:
```
SLF4J: Found binding in [jar:file:/hdata/1/yarn/local/usercache/druid/filecache/1201/slf4j-log4j12-1.7.6.jar!/org/slf4j/impl/StaticLoggerBinder.class]
```
I pulled this in my own build, and I'm running this on the cluster now.

Personally I would consider removing the whole slf4j part. Also because Druid also has some semi hard links to log4j, it won't crash but it will throw a warning. Beside that, log4j is the de facto standard.

You might want to start with reading Druid concepts/design - http://druid.io/docs/0.10.0/design/ and http://druid.io/docs/0.10.0/design/design.html 

Then use http://druid.io/docs/0.10.0/tutorials/quickstart.html to setup a minimal Druid cluster to try out things. Common runtime properties/configuration and node specific runtime properties for the quickstart resides in `conf-quickstart/druid/_common` and `conf-quickstart/druid/<node_type>` directories. You can read more about them here - http://druid.io/docs/0.10.0/configuration/index.html

There are various ways druid can ingest event data like the one you mentioned - http://druid.io/docs/0.10.0/tutorials/tutorial-streams.html and http://druid.io/docs/latest/development/extensions-core/kafka-ingestion.html

For querying you can use any of the already existing libraries/UI - http://druid.io/libraries.html or create your own web service which makes json queries to Druid. I hope this was helpful.

As long as the http transport is functional and to spec (aka, no weird firewall rules on the druid side or the windows side) you should be able to use almost anything from any OS, including postman extensions for browsers.

Hi,

Is there in work in progress regard geo index and queries ?
for wgs84 coordinates, the euclidian distance is indeed the wrong one to use.
Some workaround that I thought about could be to reprocess the data before indexing to druid by 
projecting wgs84 coordinates (latitude, longitude) to a cartesian coordinates system (x, y, z)
Then the euclidian distance can give good enough estimation to the distance between 2 points (especially important for the radius filter), however I was not able to index spatialDimensions using 3 points (x,y,z), I did managed to index only using 2 points (x,y), however using only 2 points with the  euclidian distance give wrong results. (https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/636993/different-ways-for-calculating-distance-between-two-geodetic-points-give-me-diff)
Not sure also why using more then 2 points for the spatialDimensions should fail, as calculating euclidian distance can be done based on an arbitrary number of points in any N-dimensional space.

@pjain1 was this patch no good?
@pjain1 was this patch no good?

For (3.2) there's no need to wait for _handoff_ (meaning historical nodes loading the data), we just need to wait for publishing.

Regular NumberedShardSpecs should be fine. They support "extending" beyond a core set, by setting the partitionNum to something higher than the corePartitions.

This writeup makes me realize that there's a couple of things we lose by publishing early:

- Guaranteed rollup
- Atomic publishing (linear shard specs, and numbered ones with partitions outside the core set, are published piecemeal rather than as an atomic unit)

The lack of atomic publishing would mean that replacing existing data will be done non-atomically, which for some users is not acceptable. So I guess while early publishing is a useful option for other users, we would really want an option for loading large datasets "all at once" too so we can get guaranteed rollup and atomic publishing. Probably through parallelization. It could be a later patch though.

@pjain1 @jihoonson when reading #4238 I see a lot of similarities in goals between the two patches. I'm wondering if some changes to FiniteAppenderatorDriver would make them both doable a little more simply; see this thread: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4238#discussion_r115151352

Could that reduce some of the complexity from this patch, maybe making DriverHolders and the extra tracking in KafkaIndexTask unnecessary, since a single AppenderatorDriver could handle multiple handoffs?

@praveev note that this PR introduces a bug, going to be fixed in #4252. Noting that not as an abuse (I was one of the people who approved this PR with a bug as well), but for letting you know that you may want to fix it in your private builds.

@gianm didn't add suppressions, because it's quite contrary to the point of compiler warnings to "annoy" somebody and make him finally to fix problems. Also a large portion of all warnings are [MissingOverride] that I'm going to make an error pattern and resolve in a follow-up PR.

This was brought up previously as a default compiler in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1271 and it was noted that unless there's a very strong way to track errorprone vs the default java compiler, it is not worth the complication of using a non-default compiler as the binary creator. Which is why the profile for `strict` was added. Can you show the guarantees that errorprone and the default maven compiler produce the exact same bytecode?

@gianm I read your comment about design change. 

In the new design I am not sure how a single AppenderatorDriver can support multiple active segments for same interval. For example, when maxRowsInSegmentLimit is reached a checkpoint (set of partitionOffset) is decided on by replica tasks. Now when each replica fetches records from Kafka then depending on offset they decide which driver should the record go to, the driver before the checkpoint or the one after that. I am not sure if my explanation is clear enough if not I will try to explain it more.

@leventov that issue seems to relate to mis-overriding ```install``` step. Our travis looks working well with the parallelizing option. [Here](https://travis-ci.org/druid-io/druid/builds/230140537#L3852) is an example. You can see [two processes for testing different classes start simultaneously](https://travis-ci.org/druid-io/druid/builds/230140537#L3961).

Hmm. I was thinking that the replicas would sort of chill out for a bit when it's checkpoint time, and nobody would read past the checkpoint until they agree on what it is.

Or, instead of that, would it work to do something like:

- `add` has an ability to have a set of active segments for each sequenceName, so we could use a different sequence for each checkpoint block
- `finish` / `publish` would probably need to learn about sequenceNames, so we could tell it just to push the segments for a particular set of sequenceNames.

In this world each checkpoint block would have its own sequenceName but they would all be managed by the same AppenderatorDriver. And AppenderatorDriver, I suppose, would want to track metadata separately for each pending publish.

Would something like that allow us to avoid the need for a checkpoint table and DriverHolders?
@gianm it looks that code reviews for #4198 are almost done except some comments on documents. If so, I'll merge it to this pr.
